Award.AwardTitle: Documenting Experiences and Resources Supporting the Community College Transfer, Persistence, and Graduation of Black Engineering Students

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration: While scholars have often focused on the role of K-12 schools and four-year colleges and universities in the production of future Black engineers, far less is known about the impact of community colleges in regard to their ability to support this underrepresented population. Understanding the role of community colleges is particularly important, given the large numbers of Black students that enroll in these schools prior to transitioning to four-year engineering programs. Furthermore, there is evidence to suggest that a substantial number of Black engineering students who start their postsecondary careers at community colleges may in fact be first-generation Americans from sub-Saharan African countries. This study will illuminate factors that are cited by diverse Black engineering prospective and current transfer students from Maryland community colleges as critical to their ability to persist in their majors. The research team will lead a three-year study of cohorts of Black American and Black African undergraduates who plan to or have already transferred from a Maryland community college to the A. James Clark School of Engineering at the University of Maryland. Over the duration of the project, the team will not only query the study participants about what has led to their ability to continue in their majors, but will also reveal differences between the academic paths of students born and educated in the U.S., compared to those who were educated in another country. In the context of the recent announcement of the Building Together campaign, which afforded the University of Maryland the largest gift in the history of the campus and which includes specific support for engineering transfer students, this project is especially relevant for the Clark School and community colleges in the state. Furthermore, the project leverages the already strong history that the state of Maryland has with regard to developing support programs and policies for prospective transfer students. Through this study, the University and state of Maryland will be poised to become national leaders in identifying factors that lead to the production of diverse engineering transfer students. <br/><br/>This research study builds upon the growing number of studies in engineering education and higher education literature that highlight the centrality of the community college experience to STEM students. The project also leverages recent works in education and social science scholarship that reveal the importance of documenting within-group differences among students broadly classified as Black or African American. Collectively, these works reveal noteworthy differences in the K-12 and college/university experiences of students who represent various areas of the African diaspora. Foregrounded by these studies, the research team in this project will examine factors cited by diverse Black collegians as crucial to their success before, during, and after transfer from a Maryland two-year college to the A. James Clark School of Engineering at the University of Maryland. The team will employ a longitudinal design that will enable them to study three cohorts of students at multiple points along the engineering pipeline. Using primarily qualitative methods that include focus groups and interviews, researchers will analyze transcripts using systematic and inductive coding methods to identify prominent themes that consistently appear throughout the study. In order to explicate the academic experiences of two distinct Black populations - Blacks born and educated in the U.S. and Blacks born and educated in sub-Saharan African contexts - the team will develop separate interview and focus group protocols that reflect potential areas of convergence and divergence between the two populations. Broad dissemination of project results will be accomplished through a website, brochure, and one or more webinars, as well as engagement with key stakeholders representing diverse regions of the country.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes/findings from this project address themes around student engagement and the transfer process for Black engineering students who initially enroll in community colleges. The first major finding is that community colleges that the Black engineering students attended were exceptionally supportive. Their community colleges, which were majority-minority or largely-minority serving institutions, provided an environment in which faculty and staff were tremendous resources. Faculty were approachable and showed a true interest in the transfer and overall educational aspirations of the students, which is very similar to what has been reported in other minority serving institutions. Community college staff, such as advisors, provided useful information on transfer, but also details about scholarships and other co-curricular opportunities that could benefit them holistically. These positive experiences contrast considerably from the often-disconcerting interactions that Black and other underrepresented engineering students have reported in four-year predominately White institution (PWIs). As a contribution to engineering education research, this work emphasizes the value of community colleges, which have often been underexplored in studies to date (see attached figure for more details).

Our second major finding was that the participants in our research described transfer processes that they navigated with little to no institutional support. Students self-navigated through confusing transfer information on websites and in one case reported receiving incorrect transfer admission results from the four-year institution. Participants frequently talked about maneuvering through their transfer journeys by figuring out the details for transfer individually or amongst their peers. This differed tremendously from the outcomes associated with students’ community colleges, which, again, were extremely supportive by comparison. We note in this paper how significant it is that students are leaving supportive, often majority-Black or other minority serving institutions, and entering a challenging transfer space in PWIs. We also suggest that four-year institutions can draw promising practices from minority-serving community colleges.

A third outcome of our project was that even after transfer, students continued to encounter difficulty after the logistics of transitioning from their community colleges was complete. Undergraduates in our study referenced having to acclimate to unwritten academic norms on the four-year campus that they needed to learn in order to be successful. Examples of these norms included figuring out how to access the learning management system and becoming familiar with the idea of teaching assistants. There were also differences in the grading conventions that faculty used in community colleges compared to their new four-year campus. We note that for a population that is already underrepresented in engineering and that has frequently encountered marginalization, the four-year institution – particularly the PWIs – can pose especially considerable challenges in the context of transfer. In an upcoming manuscript, we also plan to look at how foreign-born Blacks describe issues around race, ethnicity and culture in the transition from two-year to the four-year PWI engineering environment.

As researchers and practitioners continue to look for innovative ways to expand the engagement, retention and ultimately the graduation of Black engineering transfer students, our results suggest that the community college/transfer pathway is an important vehicle for achieving these diversity goals. Community colleges, particularly minority serving community colleges, represent diverse, important, and often-overlooked starting points for Black collegians. However, the four-year engineering campus transition and journey toward graduation can present numerous obstacles. We suggest that the transition from community college to four-year engineering programs should receive greater attention. In addition, we suggest that post-secondary institutions consider the value of four-year historically Black colleges and universities (HBCUs). To date, most of the research on transfer both in engineering and in non-engineering disciplines has focused on PWIs. Thus, research on the experiences of Black engineering transfers at HBCUs represents future work on this topic.
